The Earth revolves around the Sun.
The human body has 206 bones.
Water is composed of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom.
Photosynthesis is the process by which plants make food.
The largest planet in the solar system is Jupiter.
The smallest planet in the solar system is Mercury.

The Big Bang theory explains the origin of the universe.

The Renaissance was a period of cultural rebirth in Europe.
Shakespeare wrote plays like Hamlet and Romeo and Juliet.

Charles Darwin developed the theory of evolution.

Penguins are native to the Southern Hemisphere.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
Honey never spoils; archaeologists have found edible honey in ancient Egyptian tombs.
The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons.
Lightning is hotter than the surface of the Sun.
The Great Sphinx of Giza is one of the largest monolithic statues in the world.
The Mariana Trench is the deepest point in Earth's oceans.
Diamonds are formed under high pressure and temperature conditions deep within the Earth.
Chocolate was once used as currency by the Aztecs.
Mars is home to the largest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons.
Venus spins in the opposite direction of most planets.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun.
The average human body contains enough carbon to fill about 9,000 pencils.
The Andromeda Galaxy is the closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way.
A group of crows is called a murder.
Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day.
The Amazon River is the second-longest river in the world.
Butterflies taste with their feet.
Sharks have been around longer than dinosaurs.
The Great Fire of London occurred in 1666.
Albert Einstein won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.
The Rubik's Cube was invented in 1974.
The Pythagorean theorem states that a² + b² = c² in a right triangle.
The quadratic formula is x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / 2a.
Pi (π) is approximately 3.14159 and is used to calculate the circumference and area of a circle.
The area of a triangle is 0.5 × base × height.
The volume of a sphere is (4/3)πr³.
The derivative of sin(x) is cos(x), and the derivative of cos(x) is -sin(x).
Newton's first law of motion states that an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an external force.
The formula for force is F = ma (Force equals mass times acceleration).
Einstein's equation E = mc² shows the relationship between energy, mass, and the speed of light.
Acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s².
The speed of sound in air is approximately 343 meters per second at 20°C.
An atom consists of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
The atomic number of an element is the number of protons in its nucleus.
H₂O is the chemical formula for water.
NaCl is the chemical formula for table salt.
DNA stands for deoxyribonucleic acid and carries genetic information.
The human body has 23 pairs of chromosomes.
The mitochondria is known as the powerhouse of the cell.
Photosynthesis occurs in the chloroplasts of plant cells.
The formula for photosynthesis is 6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂.
The periodic table has 118 known elements.
The Law of Conservation of Mass states that mass cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction.
Electricity flows through a conductor, typically made of copper or aluminum.
Ohm's Law states that V = IR (Voltage equals current times resistance).
The unit of power is the watt (W).
A parallel circuit has multiple paths for electricity to flow.
Light travels at a speed of approximately 300,000 kilometers per second in a vacuum.
Sound waves are longitudinal waves that require a medium to travel through.
The boiling point of water is 100°C (212°F) at sea level.
Absolute zero is the lowest temperature possible and is 0 Kelvin or -273.15°C.
A mole in chemistry represents 6.022 × 10²³ particles of a substance.
The Richter scale measures the magnitude of earthquakes.
The human brain has two hemispheres, the left and right.
The heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles.
Blood is pumped through the body by the heart and carried by arteries, veins, and capillaries.
The three states of matter are solid, liquid, and gas.
Plasma is the fourth state of matter.
The formula for kinetic energy is KE = 0.5 × m × v².
Potential energy is stored energy and is calculated as PE = m × g × h.
The center of gravity is the point where an object's weight is evenly distributed.
The SI unit for temperature is the Kelvin (K).
Magnets have two poles: north and south.
Electromagnetic waves include radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
The solar system has eight planets orbiting the Sun.
A light year is the distance light travels in one year, about 9.46 trillion kilometers.
The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection.
An isosceles triangle has two equal sides.
A prime number is a number greater than 1 that has no divisors other than 1 and itself.
The Fibonacci sequence begins with 0, 1 and each subsequent number is the sum of the previous two.
The density of a substance is calculated as mass divided by volume (ρ = m/v).
In probability, the likelihood of an event occurring is expressed as a number between 0 and 1.
Vectors have both magnitude and direction, while scalars have only magnitude.
The formula for the area of a circle is A = πr².
The Celsius and Fahrenheit scales can be converted using the formula: F = (C × 9/5) + 32.
The Moon orbits the Earth approximately every 27.3 days.
Comets are made of ice and dust and have tails that point away from the Sun.
The Hubble Space Telescope has provided valuable data about distant galaxies.
The Doppler Effect describes the change in frequency of a wave as the source and observer move relative to each other.
The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way.
The speed of a computer processor is measured in gigahertz (GHz).
HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language.
CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
JavaScript is a programming language commonly used in web development.
Python is known for its readability and simplicity.
Java is a widely-used programming language that runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).
C++ is an extension of the C programming language with object-oriented features.
The Turing Test is a measure of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior.
Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence focused on building systems that learn from data.
Blockchain is a decentralized ledger technology used in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.
Quantum computing uses quantum bits or qubits to perform calculations.
The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of physical devices connected to the internet.
Augmented reality (AR) overlays digital information onto the real world.
Virtual reality (VR) immerses users in a completely digital environment.
The first programming language was created by Ada Lovelace in the 19th century.
The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) sets standards for web technologies.
HTTP stands for HyperText Transfer Protocol.
HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, using encryption to protect data.
SQL stands for Structured Query Language and is used for managing databases.
NoSQL databases are designed to handle large volumes of unstructured data.
RESTful APIs use HTTP requests to perform CRUD operations on resources.
JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation and is a lightweight data interchange format.
XML stands for eXtensible Markup Language and is used to encode documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
Git is a version control system used to track changes in source code.
GitHub is a platform for hosting and collaborating on Git repositories.
Continuous Integration (CI) is a practice where developers frequently integrate code into a shared repository.
Continuous Deployment (CD) is the practice of automatically deploying code changes to production.
The first programmable computer was the Z3, invented by Konrad Zuse in 1941.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971.
The first web browser was called WorldWideWeb, later renamed Nexus.
Linux is an open-source operating system created by Linus Torvalds.
The first smartphone was the IBM Simon, released in 1994.
The first video game, Pong, was released by Atari in 1972.
The first search engine was Archie, created in 1990.
The first social media platform was Six Degrees, launched in 1997.
The first 1GB hard drive was introduced by IBM in 1980.
The first computer virus was called Creeper, created in 1971.
The first graphical user interface was developed by Xerox PARC.
The first 3D printer was created by Chuck Hull in 1983.
The first commercial microprocessor was the Intel 4004, released in 1971.
The first digital camera was created by Kodak in 1975.
The first website was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991.
The first computer mouse was invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964.
The first programming language was Fortran, developed in the 1950s.
The first computer network was ARPANET, established in 1969.
The first laptop computer was the Osborne 1, released in 1981.
The first computer game, Spacewar!, was created in 1962.
The first mobile phone call was made by Martin Cooper in 1973.
The first computer virus for MS-DOS was Brain, created in 1986.
The first web search engine was WebCrawler, launched in 1994.
The first instant messaging service was ICQ, launched in 1996.
The first commercial internet service provider was The World, launched in 1989.
The first computer with a hard disk drive was the IBM 305 RAMAC, introduced in 1956.
The first computer to beat a human at chess was Deep Blue, developed by IBM.
The first computer to pass the Turing Test was Eugene Goostman in 2014.
The first computer to win Jeopardy! was IBM's Watson in 2011.
The first computer to play Go at a professional level was AlphaGo, developed by DeepMind.
The first university in the world is the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Morocco, founded in 859.
The oldest university in the English-speaking world is the University of Oxford.
The first woman to receive a Ph.D. was Elena Cornaro Piscopia in 1678.
The first Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen in 1901.
The first person to win two Nobel Prizes was Marie Curie, in Physics and Chemistry.
The first computer science degree program was established at Purdue University in 1962.
The SAT is a standardized test widely used for college admissions in the United States.
The first modern research university was the University of Berlin, founded in 1810.
The Ivy League is a group of eight private colleges in the northeastern United States.
The first student loan program in the United States was established in 1958.
The first online university was the University of Phoenix, founded in 1989.
The first open-access journal was the Journal of Medical Internet Research, launched in 1999.
The first Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) was offered by Stanford University in 2011.
The first academic journal was the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, established in 1665.
The first student exchange program was the Fulbright Program, established in 1946.
The first academic conference was the International Congress of Mathematicians, held in 1897.
The first academic library was the Library of Alexandria, founded in the 3rd century BCE.
The first student government was established at the University of Bologna in the 12th century.
The first academic honor society in the United States was Phi Beta Kappa, founded in 1776.
The sum of the angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees.
The sum of the angles in a quadrilateral is 360 degrees.
A parallelogram has opposite sides that are equal and parallel.
The area of a rectangle is length × width.
The area of a square is side².
The area of a circle is πr².
The circumference of a circle is 2πr.
The volume of a cube is side³.
The volume of a cylinder is πr²h.
The volume of a cone is (1/3)πr²h.
The volume of a rectangular prism is length × width × height.
The surface area of a sphere is 4πr².
The surface area of a cylinder is 2πr(h + r).
An equilateral triangle has all three sides and angles equal.
The diagonal of a rectangle is √(length² + width²).
A right triangle has one angle equal to 90 degrees.
The distance formula is √((x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²).
The midpoint formula is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
The slope of a line is (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁).
The equation of a line in slope-intercept form is y = mx + b.
The equation of a circle is (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r².
The factorial of n (n!) is the product of all positive integers up to n.
The number of permutations of n items is n!.
The number of combinations of n items taken r at a time is C(n, r) = n! / [r!(n - r)!].
A prime number is divisible only by 1 and itself.
A composite number has more than two factors.
The greatest common divisor (GCD) is the largest number that divides two numbers.
The least common multiple (LCM) is the smallest number divisible by two numbers.
The square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides in a right triangle.
The golden ratio is approximately 1.618.
A parabola is the graph of a quadratic function y = ax² + bx + c.
A circle has infinite lines of symmetry.
The harmonic mean of two numbers is 2ab / (a + b).
An arithmetic sequence has a constant difference between terms.
The nth term of an arithmetic sequence is a₁ + (n - 1)d.
The sum of an arithmetic series is n/2 × (a₁ + aₙ).
A geometric sequence has a constant ratio between terms.
The nth term of a geometric sequence is a₁ × rⁿ⁻¹.
The sum of an infinite geometric series is a₁ / (1 - r) if |r| < 1.
The determinant of a 2x2 matrix [[a, b], [c, d]] is ad - bc.
The transpose of a matrix is obtained by flipping rows and columns.
A matrix is symmetric if it equals its transpose.
A unit vector has a magnitude of 1.
The dot product of two vectors is u·v = |u||v|cos(θ).
The cross product of two vectors results in a vector perpendicular to both.
The standard deviation measures the spread of data in a dataset.
The mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values.
The median is the middle value in a sorted dataset.
The mode is the most frequently occurring value in a dataset.
The range is the difference between the highest and lowest values.
A histogram represents the frequency distribution of data.
The probability of an event is the ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes.
The binomial theorem expands (a + b)ⁿ.
A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero.
The identity matrix has ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere.
The angle sum of a polygon with n sides is (n - 2) × 180 degrees.
A regular polygon has all sides and angles equal.
The exterior angle of a regular polygon is 360°/n.
The reciprocal of a fraction a/b is b/a.
Logarithms are the inverse of exponentiation.
log(ab) = log(a) + log(b).
log(a/b) = log(a) - log(b).
log(aⁿ) = n × log(a).
The natural logarithm has a base of e (approximately 2.718).
The sine function is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle.
The cosine function is the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse.
The tangent function is the ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent side.
The unit circle has a radius of 1.
The sum of the interior angles of a pentagon is 540 degrees.
A hexagon has six sides and its interior angle sum is 720 degrees.
The discriminant of a quadratic equation determines the nature of its roots.
The roots of a quadratic equation are real if the discriminant is non-negative.
An ellipse has two focal points.
A hyperbola has two branches that mirror each other.
A cube root of a number x is a number y such that y³ = x.
A perfect square is a number that can be expressed as the square of an integer.
The modulus operation finds the remainder when one number is divided by another.
A complex number has a real and an imaginary part.
The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero on the number line.
The equation y = mx represents a proportional relationship.
An asymptote is a line that a graph approaches but never touches.
The power rule in calculus states that d/dx(xⁿ) = n × xⁿ⁻¹.
The integral of xⁿ is (xⁿ⁺¹)/(n+1) + C for n ≠ -1.
Euler's formula is e^(iθ) = cos(θ) + i sin(θ).
The area of a trapezoid is 0.5 × (base₁ + base₂) × height.
A rhombus has all sides equal and opposite angles equal.
The centroid of a triangle is the intersection of its medians.
A scalar is a quantity with magnitude but no direction.
A unit circle equation is x² + y² = 1.
Newton's first law of motion states that an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force.
Newton's second law of motion states that F = ma, where F is force, m is mass, and a is acceleration.
Newton's third law of motion states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
The law of universal gravitation states that F = G(m₁m₂)/r², where G is the gravitational constant.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 3 × 10⁸ m/s.
The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s².
Work is defined as W = Fd cos(θ), where F is force, d is displacement, and θ is the angle between them.
Power is the rate of doing work, calculated as P = W/t.
Kinetic energy is given by KE = 0.5 × m × v².
Potential energy is given by PE = m × g × h.
The total mechanical energy of a system is the sum of kinetic and potential energy.
The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Momentum is the product of mass and velocity, p = mv.
Impulse is the change in momentum, given by F × Δt = Δp.
The center of mass is the point where an object's mass is evenly distributed.
The moment of inertia is the rotational equivalent of mass, depending on the axis of rotation.
Torque is calculated as τ = r × F × sin(θ).
The angular momentum of a rotating object is L = Iω, where I is the moment of inertia and ω is angular velocity.
The first law of thermodynamics states that energy is conserved in a system.
The second law of thermodynamics states that entropy in an isolated system always increases.
The third law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a system approaches zero as temperature approaches absolute zero.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is moles, R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.
The specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise 1 kg of a substance by 1°C.
The heat transfer equation is Q = mcΔT.
Thermal expansion is given by ΔL = αL₀ΔT.
Wave speed is given by v = fλ, where f is frequency and λ is wavelength.
The period of a wave is T = 1/f.
Sound is a longitudinal wave that requires a medium to travel through.
The Doppler effect describes the change in frequency of a wave due to the motion of the source or observer.
The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
Light exhibits both wave-like and particle-like behavior.
The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection.
Snell's law describes refraction, n₁sin(θ₁) = n₂sin(θ₂).
Total internal reflection occurs when light passes from a denser medium to a less dense medium and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
The electric field is given by E = F/q.
Electric potential energy is U = k(q₁q₂)/r.
Ohm's law states that V = IR, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance.
The power in an electric circuit is P = IV.
The resistance of a conductor depends on its length, area, and resistivity: R = ρL/A.
Capacitance is given by C = Q/V, where Q is charge and V is voltage.
The energy stored in a capacitor is U = 0.5 × C × V².
Magnetic fields are created by moving charges or current-carrying wires.
The force on a charge moving in a magnetic field is F = qvBsin(θ).
The right-hand rule helps determine the direction of magnetic forces.
Faraday's law states that a changing magnetic field induces an electromotive force (EMF) in a loop.
Lenz's law states that the induced current opposes the change in magnetic flux.
The speed of sound in air is approximately 343 m/s at 20°C.
The photoelectric effect occurs when light ejects electrons from a material.
Planck's equation relates energy and frequency: E = hf.
The energy of a photon is proportional to its frequency.
The Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to know both the position and momentum of a particle simultaneously.
The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is λ = h/p.
Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei.
Nuclear fusion is the combining of light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus.
The half-life of a radioactive substance is the time it takes for half of the material to decay.
Alpha particles are helium nuclei, beta particles are high-energy electrons, and gamma rays are high-energy photons.
Einstein's equation, E = mc², relates mass and energy.
The standard model of particle physics describes the fundamental particles and their interactions.
Gravitational potential energy is U = -G(m₁m₂)/r.
A black hole is a region of space where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape.
The Big Bang theory describes the origin of the universe.
Hubble's law states that the velocity of a galaxy is proportional to its distance from us.
The speed of light is the maximum speed at which information can travel.
Work done in a circular path by a conservative force is zero.
The Bernoulli principle explains how the pressure in a fluid decreases as its velocity increases.
Hooke's law states that F = -kx for an elastic spring.
The critical angle occurs when light travels from a denser to a less dense medium.
The energy of a simple harmonic oscillator is proportional to the square of its amplitude.
The spring constant (k) measures the stiffness of a spring.
Terminal velocity occurs when the force of gravity is balanced by air resistance.
The buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by an object.
Coulomb's law describes the force between two charges: F = k(q₁q₂)/r².
The period of a pendulum is T = 2π√(L/g).
The efficiency of a machine is given by Efficiency = (Useful work output / Work input) × 100%.
Angular velocity is measured in radians per second.
The Coriolis effect explains the deflection of moving objects due to Earth's rotation.
The escape velocity from Earth is approximately 11.2 km/s.
Superconductors have zero electrical resistance at low temperatures.
A solenoid is a coil of wire that generates a magnetic field when current flows through it.
The triple point of water is 0.01°C and 611.657 Pa.
Absolute zero is the lowest temperature possible, 0 K or -273.15°C.
Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.
A cyclotron accelerates charged particles using a magnetic field.
The Mach number is the ratio of an object's speed to the speed of sound.
A laser produces coherent and monochromatic light.
An isothermal process occurs at constant temperature.
An adiabatic process occurs without the exchange of heat.
The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world.
The tallest building in the world is the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, standing at 828 meters.
The speed of sound is approximately 343 meters per second in air at 20°C.
The first man to walk on the moon was Neil Armstrong in 1969.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance.'
The fastest land animal is the cheetah, capable of speeds up to 75 mph.
Bananas are berries, but strawberries are not.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the sun, approximately 5,500°C.
Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system, with surface temperatures over 450°C.
Sharks existed before trees in Earth's history.
The Eiffel Tower can be 15 cm taller in the summer due to heat expansion.
The Amazon River is the largest river by discharge volume of water.
The world's smallest country is Vatican City, covering only 44 hectares.
The honeybee is the only insect that produces food eaten by humans.
Mount Everest is located in the Himalayan mountain range.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all the landmasses on Earth combined.
A leap year occurs every 4 years, except for years divisible by 100 but not 400.
The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar on August 27, 1896, lasting only 38 minutes.
Jupiter has the most moons of any planet in the solar system, with 95 confirmed moons as of 2025.
The scientific name of the domestic cat is *Felis catus*.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.
The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have lived on Earth.
Humans share about 60% of their DNA with bananas.
Water expands when it freezes, which is why ice floats on water.
The only continent without any active volcanoes is Australia.
Lightning strikes Earth about 100 times every second.
Honey never spoils and has been found in ancient Egyptian tombs still edible.
The speed of light in a vacuum is 299,792 kilometers per second.
Penguins can drink seawater thanks to a gland that filters out salt.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the Earth's beaches.
Antarctica is the coldest, driest, and windiest continent on Earth.
Thomas Edison held over 1,000 patents during his lifetime.
A sneeze can travel up to 100 miles per hour.
The heaviest recorded watermelon weighed 159 kilograms (about 350 pounds).
Sloths can take up to a month to digest their food.
Gold is the only metal that is yellow or golden in color.
Avocados are fruits and are sometimes called 'alligator pears.'
The longest word in the English language is 189,819 letters long and is the name of a protein called titin.
Wombat poop is cube-shaped.
The Milky Way galaxy is on a collision course with the Andromeda galaxy, expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years.
Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs.
Giraffes only need 5 to 30 minutes of sleep per day.
Peanuts are not nuts; they are legumes.
Venus rotates on its axis in the opposite direction to most planets in the solar system.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971.
A crocodile cannot stick its tongue out.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space with the naked eye.
The world's largest cave is Son Doong Cave in Vietnam.
The most common element in the universe is hydrogen.
Dolphins have names for each other and communicate using unique whistles.
Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day.
The word 'robot' comes from a Czech word meaning 'forced labor.'
Ants can carry objects up to 50 times their body weight.
The dot over the letter 'i' is called a tittle.
A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
The first video uploaded to YouTube was titled 'Me at the zoo.'
Ostriches can run faster than horses and the males can roar like lions.
Rubies and sapphires are both forms of the mineral corundum.
The world's largest flower, the Rafflesia arnoldii, can grow over 3 feet in diameter.
Horses and cows sleep standing up.
The human body is made up of about 60% water.
The speed at which hair grows is about 0.5 inches per month on average.
The pineapple plant takes about two years to produce fruit.
The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace in the 19th century.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.
The Japanese word 'tsunami' means 'harbor wave.'
There are 88 recognized constellations in the night sky.
The first smartphone was released by IBM in 1994 and was called Simon Personal Communicator.
Snakes can sense heat through special pits on their faces.
The moon is moving away from Earth at a rate of about 3.8 cm per year.
A bolt of lightning is five times hotter than the surface of the sun.
Polar bears have black skin under their white fur.
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world's oxygen.
Sharks do not have bones; their skeletons are made of cartilage.
The heaviest recorded pumpkin weighed 1,226 kilograms (about 2,700 pounds).
Butterflies taste with their feet.
Cats spend about 70% of their lives sleeping.
The world’s largest desert is not the Sahara but Antarctica, classified as a cold desert.
Every second, the Sun fuses approximately 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium.
A group of crows is called a murder.
Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backward.
Bamboo can grow up to 91 cm (35 inches) in a single day.
The human nose can detect over 1 trillion scents.
The longest-living vertebrate is the Greenland shark, which can live over 400 years.
The chemical symbol for gold is Au, from the Latin 'aurum.'
Shakespeare invented over 1,700 words that are still in use today.
The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.
Lake Baikal in Siberia is the deepest freshwater lake in the world.
Pigs are the only mammals besides humans that can get sunburned.
The first artificial satellite, Sputnik 1, was launched by the Soviet Union in 1957.
The first human to journey into outer space was Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
The first woman in space was Valentina Tereshkova in 1963.
The first space station was Salyut 1, launched by the Soviet Union in 1971.
The International Space Station (ISS) orbits Earth approximately every 90 minutes.
The Hubble Space Telescope was launched into low Earth orbit in 1990.
The first reusable spacecraft was the Space Shuttle, first launched in 1981.
The Mars Rover Curiosity landed on Mars in 2012.
The Voyager 1 spacecraft is the farthest human-made object from Earth.
The first successful flyby of Venus was by NASA's Mariner 2 in 1962.
The first successful flyby of Mars was by NASA's Mariner 4 in 1965.
The first spacecraft to land on the Moon was Luna 2, launched by the Soviet Union in 1959.
The first human-made object to reach the surface of another planet was Venera 7, which landed on Venus in 1970.
The first spacecraft to visit all the outer planets was Voyager 2.
The first private company to send a spacecraft to the ISS was SpaceX in 2012.
The first interstellar object detected passing through our solar system was 'Oumuamua in 2017.
The first image of a black hole was captured by the Event Horizon Telescope in 2019.
The first spacecraft to orbit Mercury was MESSENGER, launched by NASA in 2004.
The first spacecraft to land on a comet was Rosetta's Philae lander in 2014.
The first mission to Pluto was NASA's New Horizons, which flew by in 2015.
The first spacecraft to sample an asteroid was Japan's Hayabusa in 2005.
The first mission to return samples from an asteroid was NASA's OSIRIS-REx in 2020.
The first spacecraft to land on the far side of the Moon was China's Chang'e 4 in 2019.
The first mission to study the Sun up close is NASA's Parker Solar Probe, launched in 2018.
The first mission to explore the outer solar system was Pioneer 10, launched in 1972.
The first spacecraft to fly by Jupiter was Pioneer 10 in 1973.
The first spacecraft to fly by Saturn was Pioneer 11 in 1979.
The first spacecraft to fly by Uranus was Voyager 2 in 1986.
The first spacecraft to fly by Neptune was Voyager 2 in 1989.
The first spacecraft to orbit Jupiter was Galileo, launched by NASA in 1989.
The first spacecraft to orbit Saturn was Cassini, launched by NASA in 1997.
The first mission to study the Kuiper Belt is NASA's New Horizons.
The first spacecraft to land on Mars was Viking 1, launched by NASA in 1975.
The first mission to study the asteroid belt was NASA's Dawn, launched in 2007.
The first spacecraft to visit a dwarf planet was NASA's Dawn, which orbited Ceres in 2015.
The first mission to study the Sun's outer atmosphere is NASA's Parker Solar Probe.
The first spacecraft to land on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, was Huygens in 2005.
The first mission to study the outer planets' moons in detail is NASA's Galileo.
The first spacecraft to fly by a Kuiper Belt object was NASA's New Horizons in 2019.
The first mission to study the solar wind is NASA's Parker Solar Probe.
The first spacecraft to orbit an asteroid was NASA's Dawn, which orbited Vesta in 2011.
The first mission to study the Martian atmosphere is NASA's MAVEN, launched in 2013.
The first spacecraft to land on a moving comet was Rosetta's Philae lander.
The first mission to study the Sun's magnetic field is NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory.
The first spacecraft to orbit the Moon was Luna 10, launched by the Soviet Union in 1966.
The first mission to study the outer planets' rings in detail is NASA's Cassini.
The first spacecraft to land on Mars' polar region was NASA's Phoenix in 2008.
The first mission to study the Sun's poles is ESA's Solar Orbiter, launched in 2020.
The first spacecraft to orbit Venus was NASA's Magellan, launched in 1989.
The first mission to study the outer planets' atmospheres in detail is NASA's Juno, launched in 2011.
The capital of Italy is Rome.
The capital of Argentina is Buenos Aires.
The capital of South Africa is Pretoria.
The capital of Thailand is Bangkok.
The capital of Spain is Madrid.
The capital of Egypt is Cairo.
The capital of South Korea is Seoul.
The capital of Mexico is Mexico City.
The capital of Turkey is Ankara.
The capital of Indonesia is Jakarta.
The steam engine was invented by James Watt.
The theory of evolution by natural selection was proposed by Charles Darwin.
The periodic table was organized by Dmitri Mendeleev.
The first successful airplane flight was achieved by the Wright brothers in 1903.
The first computer algorithm was written by Ada Lovelace.
The first vaccine was developed by Edward Jenner for smallpox.
The first human to orbit Earth was Yuri Gagarin in 1961.
The first woman to win a Nobel Prize was Marie Curie in 1903.
The first president of the United States was George Washington.
The first moon landing was achieved by Apollo 11 in 1969.
The Great Pyramid of Giza is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
The Colosseum is located in Rome, Italy.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States.
The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the tallest building in the world.
The Amazon River is the largest river by discharge volume.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.
The Himalayas contain the highest peak on Earth, Mount Everest.
The Dead Sea is the lowest point on Earth's surface.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world.
The currency of Japan is the yen.
The currency of the United Kingdom is the pound sterling.
The currency of India is the rupee.
The currency of Russia is the ruble.
The currency of Australia is the Australian dollar.
The currency of Brazil is the real.
The currency of South Africa is the rand.
The currency of Mexico is the peso.
The currency of Saudi Arabia is the riyal.
The currency of Switzerland is the Swiss franc.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971.
The first website was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991.
The first smartphone was released by IBM in 1994.
The first programmable computer was the Z3, invented by Konrad Zuse in 1941.
The first computer virus was called Creeper, created in 1971.
The first graphical user interface was developed by Xerox PARC.
The first 3D printer was created by Chuck Hull in 1983.
The first commercial microprocessor was the Intel 4004, released in 1971.
The first digital camera was created by Kodak in 1975.
The first computer mouse was invented by Douglas Engelbart in 1964.
The first programming language was Fortran, developed in the 1950s.
The first computer network was ARPANET, established in 1969.
The first laptop computer was the Osborne 1, released in 1981.
The first computer game, Spacewar!, was created in 1962.
The first mobile phone call was made by Martin Cooper in 1973.
The first computer virus for MS-DOS was Brain, created in 1986.
The first web search engine was WebCrawler, launched in 1994.
The first instant messaging service was ICQ, launched in 1996.
The first commercial internet service provider was The World, launched in 1989.
The first computer with a hard disk drive was the IBM 305 RAMAC, introduced in 1956.
The first computer to beat a human at chess was Deep Blue, developed by IBM.
The first computer to pass the Turing Test was Eugene Goostman in 2014.
The first computer to win Jeopardy! was IBM's Watson in 2011.
The first computer to play Go at a professional level was AlphaGo, developed by DeepMind.
The first university in the world is the University of al-Qarawiyyin in Morocco, founded in 859.
The oldest university in the English-speaking world is the University of Oxford.
The first woman to receive a Ph.D. was Elena Cornaro Piscopia in 1678.
The first Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen in 1901.
The first person to win two Nobel Prizes was Marie Curie, in Physics and Chemistry.
The first computer science degree program was established at Purdue University in 1962.
The SAT is a standardized test widely used for college admissions in the United States.
The first modern research university was the University of Berlin, founded in 1810.
The Ivy League is a group of eight private colleges in the northeastern United States.
The first student loan program in the United States was established in 1958.
The first online university was the University of Phoenix, founded in 1989.
The first open-access journal was the Journal of Medical Internet Research, launched in 1999.
The first Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) was offered by Stanford University in 2011.
The first academic journal was the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, established in 1665.
The first student exchange program was the Fulbright Program, established in 1946.
The first academic conference was the International Congress of Mathematicians, held in 1897.
The first academic library was the Library of Alexandria, founded in the 3rd century BCE.
The first student government was established at the University of Bologna in the 12th century.
The first academic honor society in the United States was Phi Beta Kappa, founded in 1776.
The sum of the angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees.
The sum of the angles in a quadrilateral is 360 degrees.
A parallelogram has opposite sides that are equal and parallel.
The area of a rectangle is length × width.
The area of a square is side².
The area of a circle is πr².
The circumference of a circle is 2πr.
The volume of a cube is side³.
The volume of a cylinder is πr²h.
The volume of a cone is (1/3)πr²h.
The volume of a rectangular prism is length × width × height.
The surface area of a sphere is 4πr².
The surface area of a cylinder is 2πr(h + r).
An equilateral triangle has all three sides and angles equal.
The diagonal of a rectangle is √(length² + width²).
A right triangle has one angle equal to 90 degrees.
The distance formula is √((x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²).
The midpoint formula is ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2).
The slope of a line is (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁).
The equation of a line in slope-intercept form is y = mx + b.
The equation of a circle is (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r².
The factorial of n (n!) is the product of all positive integers up to n.
The number of permutations of n items is n!.
The number of combinations of n items taken r at a time is C(n, r) = n! / [r!(n - r)!].
A prime number is divisible only by 1 and itself.
A composite number has more than two factors.
The greatest common divisor (GCD) is the largest number that divides two numbers.
The least common multiple (LCM) is the smallest number divisible by two numbers.
The square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides in a right triangle.
The golden ratio is approximately 1.618.
A parabola is the graph of a quadratic function y = ax² + bx + c.
A circle has infinite lines of symmetry.
The harmonic mean of two numbers is 2ab / (a + b).
An arithmetic sequence has a constant difference between terms.
The nth term of an arithmetic sequence is a₁ + (n - 1)d.
The sum of an arithmetic series is n/2 × (a₁ + aₙ).
A geometric sequence has a constant ratio between terms.
The nth term of a geometric sequence is a₁ × rⁿ⁻¹.
The sum of an infinite geometric series is a₁ / (1 - r) if |r| < 1.
The determinant of a 2x2 matrix [[a, b], [c, d]] is ad - bc.
The transpose of a matrix is obtained by flipping rows and columns.
A matrix is symmetric if it equals its transpose.
A unit vector has a magnitude of 1.
The dot product of two vectors is u·v = |u||v|cos(θ).
The cross product of two vectors results in a vector perpendicular to both.
The standard deviation measures the spread of data in a dataset.
The mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values.
The median is the middle value in a sorted dataset.
The mode is the most frequently occurring value in a dataset.
The range is the difference between the highest and lowest values.
A histogram represents the frequency distribution of data.
The probability of an event is the ratio of favorable outcomes to total outcomes.
The binomial theorem expands (a + b)ⁿ.
A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero.
The identity matrix has ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere.
The angle sum of a polygon with n sides is (n - 2) × 180 degrees.
A regular polygon has all sides and angles equal.
The exterior angle of a regular polygon is 360°/n.
The reciprocal of a fraction a/b is b/a.
Logarithms are the inverse of exponentiation.
log(ab) = log(a) + log(b).
log(a/b) = log(a) - log(b).
log(aⁿ) = n × log(a).
The natural logarithm has a base of e (approximately 2.718).
The sine function is the ratio of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right triangle.
The cosine function is the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse.
The tangent function is the ratio of the opposite side to the adjacent side.
The unit circle has a radius of 1.
The sum of the interior angles of a pentagon is 540 degrees.
A hexagon has six sides and its interior angle sum is 720 degrees.
The discriminant of a quadratic equation determines the nature of its roots.
The roots of a quadratic equation are real if the discriminant is non-negative.
An ellipse has two focal points.
A hyperbola has two branches that mirror each other.
A cube root of a number x is a number y such that y³ = x.
A perfect square is a number that can be expressed as the square of an integer.
The modulus operation finds the remainder when one number is divided by another.
A complex number has a real and an imaginary part.
The absolute value of a number is its distance from zero on the number line.
The equation y = mx represents a proportional relationship.
An asymptote is a line that a graph approaches but never touches.
The power rule in calculus states that d/dx(xⁿ) = n × xⁿ⁻¹.
The integral of xⁿ is (xⁿ⁺¹)/(n+1) + C for n ≠ -1.
Euler's formula is e^(iθ) = cos(θ) + i sin(θ).
The area of a trapezoid is 0.5 × (base₁ + base₂) × height.
A rhombus has all sides equal and opposite angles equal.
The centroid of a triangle is the intersection of its medians.
A scalar is a quantity with magnitude but no direction.
A unit circle equation is x² + y² = 1.
Newton's first law of motion states that an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force.
Newton's second law of motion states that F = ma, where F is force, m is mass, and a is acceleration.
Newton's third law of motion states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
The law of universal gravitation states that F = G(m₁m₂)/r², where G is the gravitational constant.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 3 × 10⁸ m/s.
The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s².
Work is defined as W = Fd cos(θ), where F is force, d is displacement, and θ is the angle between them.
Power is the rate of doing work, calculated as P = W/t.
Kinetic energy is given by KE = 0.5 × m × v².
Potential energy is given by PE = m × g × h.
The total mechanical energy of a system is the sum of kinetic and potential energy.
The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Momentum is the product of mass and velocity, p = mv.
Impulse is the change in momentum, given by F × Δt = Δp.
The center of mass is the point where an object's mass is evenly distributed.
The moment of inertia is the rotational equivalent of mass, depending on the axis of rotation.
Torque is calculated as τ = r × F × sin(θ).
The angular momentum of a rotating object is L = Iω, where I is the moment of inertia and ω is angular velocity.
The first law of thermodynamics states that energy is conserved in a system.
The second law of thermodynamics states that entropy in an isolated system always increases.
The third law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a system approaches zero as temperature approaches absolute zero.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is moles, R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.
The specific heat capacity is the amount of heat required to raise 1 kg of a substance by 1°C.
The heat transfer equation is Q = mcΔT.
Thermal expansion is given by ΔL = αL₀ΔT.
Wave speed is given by v = fλ, where f is frequency and λ is wavelength.
The period of a wave is T = 1/f.
Sound is a longitudinal wave that requires a medium to travel through.
The Doppler effect describes the change in frequency of a wave due to the motion of the source or observer.
The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.
Light exhibits both wave-like and particle-like behavior.
The law of reflection states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection.
Snell's law describes refraction, n₁sin(θ₁) = n₂sin(θ₂).
Total internal reflection occurs when light passes from a denser medium to a less dense medium and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.
The electric field is given by E = F/q.
Electric potential energy is U = k(q₁q₂)/r.
Ohm's law states that V = IR, where V is voltage, I is current, and R is resistance.
The power in an electric circuit is P = IV.
The resistance of a conductor depends on its length, area, and resistivity: R = ρL/A.
Capacitance is given by C = Q/V, where Q is charge and V is voltage.
The energy stored in a capacitor is U = 0.5 × C × V².
Magnetic fields are created by moving charges or current-carrying wires.
The force on a charge moving in a magnetic field is F = qvBsin(θ).
The right-hand rule helps determine the direction of magnetic forces.
Faraday's law states that a changing magnetic field induces an electromotive force (EMF) in a loop.
Lenz's law states that the induced current opposes the change in magnetic flux.
The speed of sound in air is approximately 343 m/s at 20°C.
The photoelectric effect occurs when light ejects electrons from a material.
Planck's equation relates energy and frequency: E = hf.
The energy of a photon is proportional to its frequency.
The Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that it is impossible to know both the position and momentum of a particle simultaneously.
The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is λ = h/p.
Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller nuclei.
Nuclear fusion is the combining of light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus.
The half-life of a radioactive substance is the time it takes for half of the material to decay.
Alpha particles are helium nuclei, beta particles are high-energy electrons, and gamma rays are high-energy photons.
Einstein's equation, E = mc², relates mass and energy.
The standard model of particle physics describes the fundamental particles and their interactions.
Gravitational potential energy is U = -G(m₁m₂)/r.
A black hole is a region of space where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape.
The Big Bang theory describes the origin of the universe.
Hubble's law states that the velocity of a galaxy is proportional to its distance from us.
The speed of light is the maximum speed at which information can travel.
Work done in a circular path by a conservative force is zero.
The Bernoulli principle explains how the pressure in a fluid decreases as its velocity increases.
Hooke's law states that F = -kx for an elastic spring.
The critical angle occurs when light travels from a denser to a less dense medium.
The energy of a simple harmonic oscillator is proportional to the square of its amplitude.
The spring constant (k) measures the stiffness of a spring.
Terminal velocity occurs when the force of gravity is balanced by air resistance.
The buoyant force is equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by an object.
Coulomb's law describes the force between two charges: F = k(q₁q₂)/r².
The period of a pendulum is T = 2π√(L/g).
The efficiency of a machine is given by Efficiency = (Useful work output / Work input) × 100%.
Angular velocity is measured in radians per second.
The Coriolis effect explains the deflection of moving objects due to Earth's rotation.
The escape velocity from Earth is approximately 11.2 km/s.
Superconductors have zero electrical resistance at low temperatures.
A solenoid is a coil of wire that generates a magnetic field when current flows through it.
The triple point of water is 0.01°C and 611.657 Pa.
Absolute zero is the lowest temperature possible, 0 K or -273.15°C.
Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system.
A cyclotron accelerates charged particles using a magnetic field.
The Mach number is the ratio of an object's speed to the speed of sound.
A laser produces coherent and monochromatic light.
An isothermal process occurs at constant temperature.
An adiabatic process occurs without the exchange of heat.
The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons.
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest coral reef system in the world.
The tallest building in the world is the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, standing at 828 meters.
The speed of sound is approximately 343 meters per second in air at 20°C.
The first man to walk on the moon was Neil Armstrong in 1969.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance.'
The fastest land animal is the cheetah, capable of speeds up to 75 mph.
Bananas are berries, but strawberries are not.
Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the sun, approximately 5,500°C.
Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system, with surface temperatures over 450°C.
Sharks existed before trees in Earth's history.
The Eiffel Tower can be 15 cm taller in the summer due to heat expansion.
The Amazon River is the largest river by discharge volume of water.
The world's smallest country is Vatican City, covering only 44 hectares.
The honeybee is the only insect that produces food eaten by humans.
Mount Everest is located in the Himalayan mountain range.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all the landmasses on Earth combined.
A leap year occurs every 4 years, except for years divisible by 100 but not 400.
The shortest war in history was between Britain and Zanzibar on August 27, 1896, lasting only 38 minutes.
Jupiter has the most moons of any planet in the solar system, with 95 confirmed moons as of 2025.
The scientific name of the domestic cat is *Felis catus*.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world.
The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have lived on Earth.
Humans share about 60% of their DNA with bananas.
Water expands when it freezes, which is why ice floats on water.
The only continent without any active volcanoes is Australia.
Lightning strikes Earth about 100 times every second.
Honey never spoils and has been found in ancient Egyptian tombs still edible.
The speed of light in a vacuum is 299,792 kilometers per second.
Penguins can drink seawater thanks to a gland that filters out salt.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the Earth's beaches.
Antarctica is the coldest, driest, and windiest continent on Earth.
Thomas Edison held over 1,000 patents during his lifetime.
A sneeze can travel up to 100 miles per hour.
The heaviest recorded watermelon weighed 159 kilograms (about 350 pounds).
Sloths can take up to a month to digest their food.
Gold is the only metal that is yellow or golden in color.
Avocados are fruits and are sometimes called 'alligator pears.'
The longest word in the English language is 189,819 letters long and is the name of a protein called titin.
Wombat poop is cube-shaped.
The Milky Way galaxy is on a collision course with the Andromeda galaxy, expected to merge in about 4.5 billion years.
Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs.
Giraffes only need 5 to 30 minutes of sleep per day.
Peanuts are not nuts; they are legumes.
Venus rotates on its axis in the opposite direction to most planets in the solar system.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971.
A crocodile cannot stick its tongue out.
The Great Wall of China is not visible from space with the naked eye.
The world's largest cave is Son Doong Cave in Vietnam.
The most common element in the universe is hydrogen.
Dolphins have names for each other and communicate using unique whistles.
Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day.
The word 'robot' comes from a Czech word meaning 'forced labor.'
Ants can carry objects up to 50 times their body weight.
The dot over the letter 'i' is called a tittle.
A day on Venus is longer than a year on Venus.
The first video uploaded to YouTube was titled 'Me at the zoo.'
Ostriches can run faster than horses and the males can roar like lions.
Rubies and sapphires are both forms of the mineral corundum.
The world's largest flower, the Rafflesia arnoldii, can grow over 3 feet in diameter.
Horses and cows sleep standing up.
The human body is made up of about 60% water.
The speed at which hair grows is about 0.5 inches per month on average.
The pineapple plant takes about two years to produce fruit.
The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace in the 19th century.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.
The Japanese word 'tsunami' means 'harbor wave.'
There are 88 recognized constellations in the night sky.
